December 23,1942
Gertie Darling,
Pepper came yesterday and left thepackage
with me. I am holing my breath a[nd] patience waiting until
Christmas morning to open all your gifts. There are so
many boxes from you that I do not know which one I will
peek into first. Probably I will be like Bo last year when
she likes the ribbon so much on one of her presents that
she only wanted to play with that and did not bother to
go any further.
People re wonderful in the way they still
try to have christmas out here. There a[r]e no trees, befo[re]
they were all shipped out from the mainland. Now they take
boards , bore holes in them and then stick the bracnches ofX
bushes into the hols and tnus make a tree. They are very
peculiar looking[,]but you see them through the windows of
the houses all covered over with tinsels and bits of xxxxxxx
colored cloth when tinsel was not available. The only thing
is there are not any little white children to enjoy christmas.
Only little japs and orientals. Usually at this time of year
you see children on the streets with eyes as big as saucers.
I miss them quite a lot, they are such an intergral part of
the season.
The weather is very hot. The sky has cle red
and the sun beats down out of a cloudless blue all day so
that I am glad to be inside and when I have togo form
buliding to building I am covered with perspiration. It seems
sos_trange to read of the snow and ice in the states, and of
your freezing at twenty or fifteen degrees when I sleep without
payjamas or a sheet. The sun is just rising when we leave
our apartment in the [M]orning at seven and the doves
are cooing and flying above the canal in long sweeping flights.
Those lovely mountains that lie back from the coast are dark
blue with their va_lleys filled to the brim with mist and soft
cl ouds that seem to be rising up to meet the first shafts
of light. The air has that wonderful softness and warm freshness
that we have always remembered in tropical lands and the
waters of the can[a]l m_rror the tall palms that fringe its
course. Morris and I are always thrilled with the beggining
of this ride, then as we a ro ch honolulu the traffice becomes
heavy and after passing thru the city it is impossible. All
the world seems to be on the road to Pe rl Harbor and youstop
and st[A]rt as you sl[o]wly corscew your way along. Several men
have said frnakly that they prefer Guadalcanl to Morris's
driving in in the morning. The risk is so much less they clai[M]
[End Page 1]
Once we arrive and leave the trembling shaking car le ning
against a tree life ag in becomes normal. We enter the
BOQ for breakfast and wait in line to enter the dinning room.
At the door you pay thirty cents for a ticket and then enter
an almost square room at the far end of which there is a
long monel metal counter. Here you pick up your tray, plates
and cutlery and approach the first guardian of the food.
A wonderful simple looking negro who c n not put the anc kes
on your plate without a terr[i]fic flourish of his laddle.
Next is the chi[p]ped beef or cornbeef hash man, a little fellow
who is always gazing into the distance so that often it is
better t o serve yourself rather than to awake him. two
shu fling steps in the line beyond is the keeper of the eggs.
Either scramble or fried , you have your choice. Also there
is no limit on the number or amount. I have seen men with as
many as six friend eggs on their plate at one time. A few
feet further on is an enormous tray xxxxx golden with pats of
butter. I usually spe r about six pats or a quarter of a
pound, pick up papai , pinapple or prunes and a glass of
orange or grapefruit joice jus t beyond the butter and then
stop in front of a wonderful enormous coffe[e] cauldron whose
bellly holds inumerable cups , so m ny in fact th t no m n
has ever plumbed the depths of this delicious fluid.
We t en select a table at which men we know are sitting and
proceed to guzzle all the goodies on thepl te. Ocassionalywe
send a mess man for more coffee of a few more waffles or pan
c kes but as a general rule I only eat one helping of
ev rything because I think we should a_ll do without in
order to aid the war effrot , don't you? Back we go to the
car and ride up to our building, graon up three flight of
steps and are helped into our chairs by solitious yeoman.
Once we re confortable settled we belch and make won[d]erful noises
until about nine when the coffee mess man announces th t fresh
coffee has been brewed. We then have a cup apeice with lots
of cream and sugar and proceed to look over the mornings mail
. If there is anything interesting we read it to one nother
aloud while sma[ck]ing our lips over some crackers or other
sm ll food that we are continualy nibbling at to keep up our
strength. I will describe the remainderof the day to yo[u]
in an_other letter as I want you to have a cle[A]r picut[r]e of my
life, and times.
Sunday was a most heavenly day. Hot sun, blue
sea with planes putting on a wonderful exhibition of dog
fighting above our heads as they practiced God only knows what.
Some of them are incredible fast and after they make a dive
zoom up and out of sight before you can open both eyes in
suprise. Fat face morris did not come back from the o fice
until lare in the afternoon so he never came on the beach and
as a result is as white as sheet, with that wonderful green
look about the gills that only executi[V]es and fu[r]heres have.
We are taking our liker r tion to our christmas dinner so even
if the food is terrible we will h ve a very good time. Did
I tell you the night I went to dinner with a captain and was
detrmined to look so smart that I made a_ll the mistakes one
can. Forgot my shoulder boards, buttons etc. I believe I
[End Page 2]
told you about it in a previous letter.
Sorry I have to quite . Lots of work. All
my love.
Sidney J. Legendre
